articles.title: Gladys Mae West obituary: mathematician who pioneered GPS technology
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 23 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00254-zShe made key contributions to US cold-war science despite facing huge barriers as a Black woman.
articles.content:
Credit: Ian Dagnall/Alamy

US mathematician Gladys Mae West was best known for her foundational work on GPS systems. As an African American woman, West overcame huge barriers to contribute to this key technology. She was one of many women of her generation whose talents helped to propel the mid-twentieth-century cold-war technology boom in the United States. Programming some of the most powerful computers of the time, West pushed the horizons of computation and communication. She has died, aged 95.

West was born in a farming family in rural Virginia. She excelled in her studies, but because of the Jim Crow laws that barred Black children from the well-funded schools that white students enjoyed, she attended a vocational-training school rather than an academically oriented secondary school. She earned a scholarship to Virginia State College, a historically Black college in Petersburg, where she was one of the few women to study mathematics. West obtained her master’s degree there in 1955.

West’s desire to find a profession that would open up possibilities for her propelled her to take up a position at a research and development centre, then called the Naval Proving Ground, Dahlgren, in Virginia. When she started, she was one of only two Black women and four Black professionals. The double burden of discrimination made West feel like an outsider among both the white women who worked at the centre — whose conversations, she recalled, would often fall silent as she approached — and her male co-workers. She was keenly aware that she should keep her head down and never “allude to the fact she had different ideas”. West was unable to travel with her colleagues because of segregation laws and missed out on opportunities as a result.

These women helped to shape quantum mechanics — it’s time to recognize them

Moreover, secrecy sometimes hid the full impact of her work from her. “We didn’t know exactly where it was going because we worked for the military where everything is secret,” West recalled. Nevertheless, she embarked on research at the centre that shaped her later accomplishments. In 1962, West worked on Project 29V in the computational division’s scientific programming and analysis branch. Her job was to calculate the orbit of Pluto in relation to Neptune. She was part of a team that programmed a computer to perform more than five billion calculations, taking nearly 100 hours of computer time. Ultimately, in 1964, the work proved the regularity of Pluto’s orbit. The research won a merit award for group achievement.

West next took a job in the Defense Mapping Agency at Dahlgren. There, she managed the SEASAT radar altimetry project — a system for data collection and processing that would model Earth’s environmental and oceanographic features. Orbiting Earth from June to October 1978, the SEASAT satellite used cutting-edge technology to help researchers to create a model of the planet’s shape, measuring sea-ice levels, the oceans’ topography and other characteristics of Earth’s largest water bodies.

After this success, West and her team used data from a US Navy satellite called GEOSAT, launched in March 1985, to create a geodetic Earth model with improved accuracy. West used an IBM 7030 Stretch supercomputer to analyse these data, accounting for variations in gravitational and tidal forces that change Earth’s shape. Stretch was an intimidating machine: so big that it would take up “the first floor of a house”, West noted.

articles.personality_title: Gladys Mae West: Mathematician behind GPS technology breaks barriers
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Gladys Mae West was an African American mathematician who helped create the technology behind GPS, the system that tells us where we are on Earth. She worked during a time when many Black people and women faced unfair treatment, especially in science and technology jobs.

**What happened** – West passed away at age 95. Born in rural Virginia, she went to a historically Black college and became one of the few women studying math. She worked at a Navy research center where she helped program powerful computers to study planets and Earth’s shape. Her work with satellites in the 1970s and 1980s helped build accurate models of Earth, which are important for GPS.

**Impact** – West’s work was key to creating GPS, a technology used every day by millions of people worldwide for navigation and mapping. Despite facing discrimination because of her race and gender, she made important discoveries that changed how we understand our planet. Her story shows how talent and determination can overcome big obstacles.

**What's next step** – West’s contributions are now being recognized more widely. Her story encourages schools and science programs to support more diverse groups of people. This can lead to new discoveries and inventions from people who have been overlooked in the past.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Gladys Mae West’s pioneering math work helped build GPS technology, proving that overcoming barriers can lead to achievements that benefit everyone.
articles.personality_title_fr: Gladys Mae West : la mathématicienne derrière la technologie GPS qui a brisé les barrières
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Gladys Mae West était une mathématicienne afro-américaine qui a aidé à créer la technologie du GPS, le système qui nous indique notre position sur Terre. Elle travaillait à une époque où de nombreuses personnes noires et femmes subissaient des discriminations, notamment dans les métiers scientifiques et technologiques.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – West est décédée à 95 ans. Née en Virginie rurale, elle a étudié dans un collège historiquement noir et était l’une des rares femmes à étudier les mathématiques. Elle a travaillé dans un centre de recherche de la Marine où elle a aidé à programmer de puissants ordinateurs pour étudier les planètes et la forme de la Terre. Son travail avec des satellites dans les années 1970 et 1980 a permis de créer des modèles précis de la Terre, essentiels pour le GPS.

**Impact** – Le travail de West a été crucial pour la création du GPS, une technologie utilisée chaque jour par des millions de personnes dans le monde pour la navigation et la cartographie. Malgré les discriminations liées à sa race et son genre, elle a fait des découvertes importantes qui ont changé notre compréhension de la planète. Son histoire montre que le talent et la détermination peuvent surmonter de grands obstacles.

**Prochaine étape** – Les contributions de West sont désormais mieux reconnues. Son histoire encourage les écoles et les programmes scientifiques à soutenir davantage de groupes diversifiés. Cela peut conduire à de nouvelles découvertes et inventions par des personnes souvent négligées auparavant.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le travail mathématique pionnier de Gladys Mae West a aidé à construire la technologie GPS, prouvant que surmonter les obstacles peut mener à des réalisations profitant à tous.
articles.personality_title_es: Gladys Mae West: matemática detrás de la tecnología GPS que rompió barreras
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Gladys Mae West fue una matemática afroamericana que ayudó a crear la tecnología del GPS, el sistema que nos dice dónde estamos en la Tierra. Trabajó en una época en la que muchas personas negras y mujeres enfrentaban discriminación, especialmente en trabajos de ciencia y tecnología.

**Qué pasó** – West falleció a los 95 años. Nació en una zona rural de Virginia, estudió en una universidad históricamente negra y fue una de las pocas mujeres que estudiaron matemáticas. Trabajó en un centro de investigación naval donde ayudó a programar poderosas computadoras para estudiar planetas y la forma de la Tierra. Su trabajo con satélites en los años 70 y 80 ayudó a crear modelos precisos de la Tierra, importantes para el GPS.

**Impacto** – El trabajo de West fue clave para crear el GPS, una tecnología que usan millones de personas todos los días para navegar y mapear. A pesar de la discriminación por su raza y género, hizo descubrimientos importantes que cambiaron cómo entendemos nuestro planeta. Su historia muestra que el talento y la determinación pueden superar grandes obstáculos.

**Próximo paso** – Las contribuciones de West están siendo reconocidas más ampliamente. Su historia anima a escuelas y programas científicos a apoyar a grupos más diversos. Esto puede llevar a nuevos descubrimientos e inventos de personas que antes fueron ignoradas.

**Resumen en una frase** – El trabajo pionero de Gladys Mae West en matemáticas ayudó a construir la tecnología GPS, demostrando que superar barreras puede llevar a logros que benefician a todos.
